text.p: ABSTRACT. From 1940 to 1960 across 20 large U.S. cities, rental housing's price fell, renters' in- comes rose, rent's share in household budgets fell, and, as expected, renters' real housing consumption increased. From 1970 to 2010, rental housing's price increased, renters' incomes decreased, but, un- expectedly, renters' real housing consumption increased. We find neither demographics nor housing supply factors account for the anomalous post-1970 increase in renters' housing consumption. We conclude that after 1970 there was a nationwide increase in renters' preferences for housing consump- tion. With incomes falling, renters increased housing consumption by decreasing consumption of other necessities including food, clothing, and transportation.

Virtually all Americans have been renters in the housing market at some point in their lives-as young adults starting out, during life transitions such as divorce or job change, or as senior citizens downsizing from the family home. For low-and moderate- income Americans, rental housing is often the only viable option available because their incomes and savings are insufficient to finance the purchase of a home and to pay the costs of upkeep over time. As the subprime mortgage crisis underscores, homeownership is not for everyone. According to the 2010 Census, just over a third of all U.S. households lived in rented dwellings. For most renters, like most homeowners, the cost of housing absorbs a significant portion of household income. In this paper, we explore the changing circumstances of renters in 20 of the largest U.S. urban housing markets over the past seven decades, with special attention to the past four decades. We focus on providing a unique, long-term view of changes in the income of renters, the rents they pay, and the quantity of housing they consume. Decennial census data reveal that from 1930 to 1970, most renters' incomes rose while the price of rental housing services fell. In contrast, from 1970 to 2010, most renters' incomes fell and the price of rental housing services rose. We break down the post-1970 changing distribution of rents into changes in the price of rental housing services and

changes in quantity of rental housing services consumed. Here we encounter a striking puzzle that has not been documented in the existing literature. Despite falling renter incomes and increasing prices of rental housing services, since 1970 renters have markedly increased their consumption of rental housing services, which leads us to ask whether demographic changes might have driven changes in consumption separately from changes in incomes and prices. The answer is mixed: an estimated demand function confirms that demographics do matter-most notable, renting baby-boomers and their successors consume markedly more housing than do people born prior to World War II-but there remain large increases over time in housing consumption that are not accounted for by incomes, prices, or demographics. Do supply factors account for the increased housing consumption of renters? Our evidence suggests that supply considerations do not provide an explanation. The budget constraint implies that changes in rent's budget share must be accom- panied by offsetting changes in other goods' budget shares. We turn in the last section of the paper to documenting these changes in other goods' budget shares over the past eight decades using the Consumer Expenditure Survey (CEX). Examining expenditure shares of renters from 1935 to 2011, we find that rent's budget share generally increases over the time span, peaking in 2011. From 1935 through the early 1970s the increases in rent's budget share are offset by declines in food's share. Since the 1970s, food's budget share has largely flattened. From the early 1970s through 2011, increases in rent's bud- get share and similar increases in "Other" spending are offset by decreases in the budget shares of food, transport, and clothing. Our evidence suggests that the usual suspects (demographics, supply factors) do not explain the increase in the housing consumption of renters. While there is certainly room for more research to explain the phenomenon, our analysis suggests that there has been a fundamental change in the tastes of renters; they have a stronger preference for housing consumption.
2. TWO MODELS OF HOUSING

With our focus on the long-term changes in renter incomes, rents paid, and housing services consumed, this paper builds on the extensive housing affordability literature. In a widely cited paper, Quigley and Raphael (2004) summarize the evidence that between 1960 and 2000, lower income renters sharply increased the fraction of their income spent on rent. 1 While some analysts bemoan rental housing's unaffordability, 2 some note that the increased spending has brought a reduction in the numbers of households living in

1 The Harvard Joint Center for Housing Studies reports that "the share of US households unable to find affordable rentals has been on the rise for a half-century, with an especially large jump in the last decade" and "affordability is likely to deteriorate further over the next few years" (Joint Center for Housing Studies, 2011). For many years there was much concern about the "adequacy" of rental housing; prior to 1960, many units lacked basic plumbing and heating or were markedly overcrowded. For example, in 1949 many large families lived in small quarters and more than 40 percent of units lacked complete indoor plumbing (Gabriel, 1996). In the mid-1980s, U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) analysts began counting the number of very poor households with what came to be known as "worst case housing needs." HUD found that substandard and crowded housing had become very infrequent problems, while housing expenditures in excess of 50 percent of income was the most often-faced problem among these households. For example, by 1993 HUD found that 95 percent of worst housing needs cases were due to rents in excess of 50 percent of income, while substandard or overcrowded housing occurred in only 9 percent of the worst housing needs cases (HUD, 1996, p. 13). 2 Among the many older papers in this vein: Clay (1987), cited by Nelson (1994) as an early voice worrying about declines in the stock of affordable housing; Apgar et al. (1991); Bogdon et al. (1994); Malpezzi and Green (1996); Orr and Peach (1999); and, more recently, Vandenbroucke (2007).

substandard housing (Weicher, 1991; Malpezzi and Green, 1996). Malpezzi and Green argue "America's poor are spending more to get better housing." Our approach to measuring rents and housing consumption is based on an extensive literature. Urban economists rely on two primary models of housing: the housing services model and the hedonic price model. In the housing services model, housing is treated as a composite commodity in which attributes of housing are collapsed into a single homogeneous good. In the hedonic price model, housing is represented as a bundle of distinct attributes, each with its own pricing. Prices in the housing services model are generally measured by price indices. The quantity of housing services is then defined as rent divided by price. The best known rental housing price index is the contract rent index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS). Prices in the hedonic price model are generally measured by regressions of rent (or house value) on a vector of housing units' characteristics. The American Housing Survey (AHS) has provided the richest source of attribute information for hedonic price estimation. Murray (1978) offers theoretical and empirical arguments that indicate that nei- ther the housing services nor the hedonic price model is uniformly more general than the other. In this light, the choice of model depends largely on what question is being asked and what data are available. For example, if the question asked is about the ben- efits accruing to households from living in public housing, as in Murray (1975), then the housing services model can suffice, while if the question asked is about changes in the quality of rental housing units over time, as in Gordon and vanGoethem (2007), then the hedonic price model can prove especially powerful. In this analysis, we rely chiefly on the housing services model, though we do present some data from the AHS on specific housing attributes.
3. THE PRICE AND QUANTITY OF RENTAL HOUSING SERVICES

The BLS contract rent index is a central component of our analysis. The BLS provides rent indices for the nation, census regions, and large metropolitan areas dating back as early as 1915. This long, time series provides a rich source of information on rents and is the best source of rent and quantity information for our purposes. The BLS index is not perfect and many researchers have addressed biases in these indices (biases we address in our analysis of the BLS data). Crone et al. (2010) report that prior to 1977 the BLS omitted from its contract rent sample units that had a change of tenant or that were vacant. Their paper presents a national contract rent index that corrects for the consequent downward bias in the BLS. They find that rental housing's price rose considerably more between 1940 and 1985 than indicated by the BLS index. Gordon and vanGoethem (2007) argue that unmeasured quality changes are a primary driver of the bias identified by Crone et al. Using a mix of data sources, Gordon and vanGoethem estimate for the period 1935-1985 a somewhat smaller bias than did Crone et al. For the period 2000-2010, Ambrose et al. (2015) provide another alternative to the BLS rent index. They restrict attention to new tenants in properties handled by property management companies. Ambrose et al. use their data to estimate city-specific rent indices from 2000 to 2010 for more cities than are covered by the BLS data; they find smaller rent increases and many more rent decreases than in the BLS contract rent data for that decade. Gordon and vanGoethem caution against using national rent indices for subnational analyses. This poses a challenge for us because there are no bias-corrected, city-specific rent indices for most of the period of interest to us. Fortunately, our central results prove

robust to choosing between the BLS city-specific indices and the national bias-corrected index of Crone et al. The city-specific price indices of the BLS and of Ambrose et el. share a limitation of all city-specific Consumer Price Index (CPI) price indices: they do not allow comparison of price levels across cities. Instead, the index is arbitrarily set to 100 in all cities in a chosen base year. However, a BLS analysis, "Three Budgets for an Urban Family of Four" (U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, 1972), prices a fixed bundle of consumption goods, including rental housing, across some 40 cities in 1970. These fixed-bundle prices, coupled with the BLS rent indices and CPI price indices, reveal differences in price levels across cities over time. Another problematic feature of the BLS rent indices has been their treatment of depreciation. For years prior to 1988, the BLS national and city-specific rent indices do not account for depreciation of housing units. Randolph notes that until 1988 the BLS indices' implied rates of change are consequently biased downward by the depreciation rate. Lowry (1982), Apgar et al. (1987), and Randolph (1988) report that the literature contains estimates from 0.3 to 0.9 percent per annum for rental housing's depreciation rate. A further problem with the BLS rent index, shared with the other indices men- tioned above, is their reliance on contract rent, i.e., on rents paid to landlords. Contract rents often include some utilities while excluding others; indeed, contract rents some- times exclude utilities altogether. Which utilities are included in contract rent has varied considerably over time and across cities. Consequently, contract rents do not provide a measure of expenditure on a consistently defined mix of housing and utilities. The oil crises of the 1970s and early 1980s increased gross rents appreciably, but these increases are missed in contract rents for units in which utilities are not included in rent. Moreover, Integrated Public Use Microsamples (IPUMS) data reveal that in the 1970s and 1980s, many landlords responded to higher utility costs by excluding utilities from rent when renegotiating rents, exacerbating the downward bias in the BLS contract rent index as a gross rent index. The U.S. Census and the American Community Survey (ACS) collect data on both contract rent and expenditure on utilities not included in rent. These data do not suffice for separating housing and utility expenditures, but they do permit the construction of "gross rent," which is the sum of housing expenditure and total utility expenditure. Appendix 1 reports how we use city-specific contract rent indices, the city- specific CPI utility price indices, the BLS 1970 budget data, and census and ACS data on contract rents and gross rents to construct city-specific "gross rent" price indices ap- propriate to measuring real gross rents. 3 We then adopt the housing services model and define the quantity of rental housing services a household consumes to be the household's gross rent divided by the city-specific gross rent price index for that consumer's location. Figure 1 shows both the BLS rent index and our gross rent price index relative to the CPI price index for all goods less shelter. 4 The BLS relative prices from 1935 to 2010 are indicated by the closely spaced symbols in Figure 1. Our relative gross rent prices for 1970-2010 are indicated by the widely spaced symbols. The bases for the two indices

However, in our regression analysis, we check for the robustness of our results to using a national gross rent index grounded in the national contract rent indices of Crone et al. (2010).

4. TWO EPOCHS FOR RENTAL HOUSING

A glance at rent-to-income ratios across time reveals two epochs for rental housing: 1940-1960 and 1970-2010. Figure 2 shows for each of five renter income quintiles, 5 us- ing census and ACS data, the ratios of mean gross rent (i.e., rent inclusive of utilities) to household income for 1940-2010. Rent-to-income ratios fell for all income quintiles
5 Throughout, individuals are assigned to quintiles within their city-specific renters' income distri- bution with individuals with negative incomes excluded from consideration.

from 1940 to 1960, 6 and, until 1970, continued to fall slightly for the wealthiest quintiles; the poorest quintiles began to see increases in their rent income ratios by 1970. Since 1970, rent income ratios have risen. Clearly, the post-1970 increases have been sharpest for renters in the poorest quintiles of the renter income distribution 7 ; but even the wealth- iest renters have seen the share spent on rent rise from 12 percent in 1970 to 18 percent in 2010. 8 What has driven the changes in rent-income ratios over time? We first consider the period of increasing affordability, 1940-1960. Then we examine the period of declining affordability, 1970-2010.

The story from 1940 to 1960 is simple: renters' incomes rose dramatically and the price of rental housing services fell substantially. Census data reveals that renters' real incomes rose 110 percent between 1940 and 1960. Because housing is income inelastic, renters opted to reduce their rent to income ratios over this period. 9 Moreover, a BLS index of the price of rental services and the CPI reveal a dramatic 33 percent drop in the relative price of rental housing services from 1935 to 1950 that has only been partially undone subsequently.

6 The 1950 Census did not collect data on rents. The ratios observed in 1940 are not simply a reflection of the end of the Depression or pre-World War II buildup conditions; the ratio of median rent to estimated median income was about the same when the Depression started as when it was ending. The 1930 Census did not gather income data, but U.S. Department of Commerce (DOC) estimates imply that real per capita income in 1940 was 15.4 percent above that of 1930 (U.S. Bureau of the Census, 1975, Series F-4, p. 224) and 1930 Census data and CPI data indicate that real rents were 6 percent lower in 1940 than in 1930. The 20 cities we study are: Atlanta, Baltimore, Boston, Cleveland, Chicago, Dallas, Detroit, Houston, Los Angeles, Miami, New York, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, Phoenix, Riverside, San Diego, San Francisco, Seattle, Tampa, and Washington DC. As shown in Table 1, the decline in the price of rental housing services coincides with a dramatic increase (11.4 percentage points) in the homeownership rate between 1940 and 1950 and a 6.9 percentage point increase from 1950 to 1960. As the demand for new, owner-occupied, single-family homes in the suburbs increased, the price of inner city rental housing fell. Incomes for both renters and homeowners grew in the post-World War II economy. Because housing demand is price inelastic, the lower price of housing services induced a further decline in the rent-to-income ratio. Higher incomes and a lower price of rental housing led to increased housing consumption; for example, the proportion of rental units without plumbing fell from nearly half in 1940 to about one in six by 1960.

Renters' fortunes reversed following 1970. Table 4 also presents the regional rates of change in real housing consumption between 1970 and 2010. Clearly, the increase in real housing consumption is a nationwide phenomenon. Such increases occurred even in the cities in which falling incomes were accompanied by the largest increases in the relative price of rental housing services. This is evidenced by the 18 14 city-specific percentage changes from 1970 to 2010 in median real housing consumption for renters in the local third income quintile that are reported in Column 3 of Table 3, The relative price changes and real housing consumption measures reported in Tables 3 and 4 are based on our gross price index and the local CPI for all goods less shelter. Had we relied solely on the BLS rent index, the real housing consumption changes would have appeared much larger than those we report. Substantial increases in real housing consumption when incomes are falling and rental housing's price is rising are very surprising. Do we see evidence of such increases in data that do not require price indices for calculating quantity? We do. The AHS has tracked the size of rental units since 1985. Table 5 reports the median square footage of rental units in 1985 and 2011. Nationally, renters occupied units 4.5 percent larger in 2011 than in 1985. The median size of rental units had grown steadily from 1985 until 2007; at that peak, units were 8 percent larger than in 1985. However, regions differed sharply in how the sizes of units changed. Rental units in the West grew steadily into 2011 (up 10.9 percent from 1985), and units in the South grew until 2008 or 2009 (and in 2011 were still up by 17.4 percent over 1985). But rental units in the Northeast and Midwest have never again been as large as they were in 1985, falling 14.1 percent and 10.6 percent, respectively, by 2011. Why do we not see in Table 4 declines in real housing consumption for renters in the Northeast and Midwest? The answer lies in housing's amenities. The AHS has tracked numerous housing amenities since 1985, and a few since 1973. Table 5 reports the frequencies of five housing amenities in 1985 and in 2011: having two

or more bathrooms, having a clothes washer, having a clothes dryer, having a dishwasher, and having central air conditioning. The proportion of units with two or more baths more than doubled between 1985 and 2011, and such increases were ubiquitous across the country. Similarly, in every region the proportion of units with central air doubled or nearly doubled over the period. The proportions of units with various appliances grew comparably in number, but from higher initial bases. Renters in the South and West have been renting more and better housing; renters in the Northeast and Midwest have been renting smaller, but better units. These trends were already underway before 1985. Between 1973 and 1985, the percentage of renters with two or more baths rose from 6.2 percent to 11.7 percent, and the percentage with central air rose from12.9 percent to 26.9 percent; the increases occurred in all regions. There is a vast literature spanning decades estimating hedonic prices of dwelling and location attributes. Sirmans et al. (2006) offer a meta-analysis of hedonic prices for numerous owner-occupied single-family dwelling characteristics. Using the models in 81 studies, coefficients on traits in semilog specifications with the log of house value as the dependent variables prove rather stable over time (with the exception of lot size) but vary somewhat with region. The meta-analysis indicates that apart from substantial changes in square footage and lot size, a change in any one specific characteristic has only a modest effect on value. With this evidence before us how are we to account for renters consuming more housing despite lower incomes and more costly housing? Have other determinants of demand driven this result? Have supply constraints somehow forced greater consumption? We turn first to demand.
5. THE DETERMINANTS OF HOUSING DEMAND

Prices and incomes are not the only determinants of housing demand. Mankiw and Weil (1989) emphasize the potential impact of demographic trends on housing demand in the owner-occupied market. Demographics are equally likely to matter for rental housing markets. Moreover, the demographic composition of renter households changed markedly after 1970 (DiPasquale and Murray, 2008). In 2010, more renter households were female headed, more were black, and more (almost three times as many) were Hispanic. Renter households were generally slightly smaller, though in some places, such as Los Angeles,
C 2016 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.

they were larger. The changes in female headship and family size occurred chiefly in the 1970s; changes in racial and ethnic makeup have occurred more steadily over time. Differences in ages of household heads across cities in any year are much sharper than the differences across time. For example, the mean ages of household heads in Dallas and New York differ by almost eight years, while the ages of all heads of households in 1970 and 2010 differ by only 1.3. However, there was an appreciable (two-year) drop in renter household heads' mean age in the 1970s that reflects both the first appearance of the very large baby-boom generation into cities' rental housing markets and the shrinking numbers of the late 19th century and early 20th century cohorts. Cohort effects might dramatically affect housing consumption. The baby-boomers grew up in the post-World War II housing boom; the generations born in the early 20th century grew up in housing far more modest than the stock built in the mid-20th century. People's early shelter experiences might shape their expectations about what constitutes adequate housing which would mean that boomers and their elders would always have very different ideas about what constitutes adequate housing. To ascertain whether changes in income, prices, or demography can account for the rise in real housing consumption reported in Tables 3 and 4, we estimate a log-log demand function for housing with detailed demographic variables, as well as prices and incomes. Table 6, column 1 reports the results from a 16 metropolitan area 15 fixed effects OLS re- gression with robust standard errors clustered by city-year. The dependent variable is the quantity of housing services consumed: gross rent in current dollars divided by the local current price of housing services. The housing price index used in column 1 is our gross rent index grounded in the BLS contract rent index (see appendix 1 for the steps required to turn a contract rent index into a gross rent index). Column 2 contains comparable re- gression results based on a gross rent index grounded in the national contract rent index of Crone et al. (2010). The goods for which prices are included in the demand equations are housing, food, medical care, transportation, and apparel, plus a price for "all other goods." 16 Food is the numeraire good: income and the prices of nonfood goods are divided by the price of food. Since demand functions are homogeneous of degree zero in prices and income, we constrain the numeraire good's cross-price elasticity with housing to be minus the sum of the estimated coefficients on income and the other prices. 17 The regression also

Baltimore, Phoenix, Tampa, and Washington DC lack some of the required price data for each year. Miami and Pittsburgh lack some required data for some years. While using a balanced panel would ensure that the year dummies cannot reflect year-to-year changes in the geographic composition of the sample, we include Miami and Pittsburgh in the OLS regressions because doing so changes almost all estimated coefficients, including the key parameters (year dummies and housing's income and own-price elasticities) only in the third decimal place-and changes no parameter appreciably. 6. CHANGING CHARACTERISTICS OF HOUSING SUPPLY

Since conventional demand analysis does not account for the increase in renters' housing consumption, we turn to supply considerations. If housing were a conventional good and unaffected by government policies, the price of housing services would suffice for capturing the effects of supply on people's consumption of housing. In that case, our instrumental variables estimates would properly account for the interactions of supply and demand. However, housing is not conventional good and housing markets are targets of government policy.

Housing services' unconventional character is that they are delivered by discrete, long-lived but physically depreciating dwellings. As housing units depreciate, they tend to become occupied by less wealthy tenants. This filtering process is a centerpiece of the housing literature. Governments' intervention in housing markets comes in two primary forms: the provision of subsidies for housing supply or demand and land use and building regulations. Lowry (1960) provides a clear intuitive account of the filtering process. Sweeney (1974) provides a definitive theoretical framework for analyzing this filtering process. Empirical work on filtering is scarce, but Rosenthal (2014) provides evidence describing the connections among housing's depreciation rate, households' price and income elastici- ties of demand, changes in the market price of housing, and the path of dwellings through the income distribution. Unfortunately, Rosenthal's work, rooted in housing demand, does not reveal the empirical structure of the dynamic interaction between housing supply and housing demand that might ideally inform our work. At the core of Sweeney's model of filtering is the notion of hierarchies of dwellings. New dwellings tend to sit at the top of the hierarchy since they tend to be of above average quality. Suppliers of these new dwellings are responsive to the housing demands of wealthier households. Households a little lower on the wealth ladder tend to choose from the slightly depreciated dwellings now abandoned by the occupants of new dwellings. Since housing quality is correlated with housing's age, housing markets with a larger share of younger units are apt to afford renters at each wealth level with better housing opportunities. In our data, when the proportion of units less than 10 and between 10 and 20 years of age and the proportion of the stock built before 1950 are added to the regression of column 1, Table 6, they prove collectively insignificant and the estimated coefficients on the year dummies are only modestly reduced. Besides recent new construction, another possibility for filtering raising renters' consumption is through increased homeownership. Often, becoming a homeowner means leaving an apartment to buy a house. Many rental units left behind by such (usually) higher income renters become available to lower income tenants. As seen in Table 1, homeownership rates were rising over much of our sample period. Did units newly available to the growing number of renters simply provide much more housing than the units occupied in 1970, leaving renters no choice but to occupy such units? The local homeownership rate, when added to the regressions in column 1 of Table 6, proves only marginally statistically significant, with an unexpectedly positive coefficient, while other coefficients are not much changed. Shifting homeownership rates do not account for the conundrum of increasing real housing consumption as renters' incomes fall and rental housing's price rises. Filtering might deny some renters the lower quality units they would prefer, but it would not drain from the stock already existing lower quality units. 8. CONCLUSION

In this paper, we document the changing fortunes of renter over eight decades with detailed attention to the past four decades. From 1940 to 1970, American renters shared in the growing prosperity of other Americans. Renters spent less of their incomes on housing while increasing the quantities of housing consumed. Since 1970, renter incomes fell, the price of rental housing services rose, but renters consumed more housing. With declining incomes, renters have faced tough choices. Their increase in housing consumption was accompanied by decreases in spending on clothing, food, and transport. The increase in renters' housing consumption while incomes fell and rents rose is a confounding puzzle. Our results show that the increases in housing consumption are far from fully explained by demographic changes in the U.S. renter population. While lack of data limit our ability to provide definitive analysis of the impact of supply fac- tors on the increase in renters' housing consumption, the evidence we do have indicate that the increases in housing consumption among renters are not due to commonly sug- gested supply factors. Filtering as measured by the age composition of the stock does not account for the increase in housing consumption. A lack of time series data on reg- ulation by city precludes us from directly assessing the role of regulation in increased housing consumption, but indirect evidence suggests that regulation has not driven those increases. Our analysis supports the claim that in the years since 1970 there has been a fundamental change in the tastes of renters-they have a stronger preference for housing consumption.
APPENDIX 1.
A Gross Price Index for Rental Housing Services

Because our analyses focus on the gross rents (that is, rents including utilities) reported in IPUMS, we need gross rent price indices to separate prices and quantities. The BLS rent index is not a gross rent price index; the BLS index is based on a sample of contract rents, some of which include utilities and some of which do not. From 1970 to 2010, the role of utilities has changed significantly. Utility costs have increased substantially and the portion of units where rents include utilities has decreased. We construct city- specific gross rent indices from the BLS city-specific contract rent indices. The IPUMS census and ACS data allow us to estimate the fraction of rents in the BLS sample that are gross rents and the fraction where contract rents do not include utilities (using numbers of households with contract rents and the numbers of households with gross rents not equal to contract rent). The IPUMS data also allow us to estimate the ratio of utility expenditures to gross rent (using those households for which reported contract rent and reported gross rent differ to infer utilities expenditures). We use the IPUMS data on the ratio of utilities to gross rent for those whose contract rents do not include utilities and on the fraction of renters whose utilities are not included in rent to convert the contract rents BLS observes into gross rents. The standard practice in building price indices is to fix the quantities in a bundle and to then track the cost of that fixed quantity over time. We track the cost of a fixed bundle of utilities by identifying a bundle of utilities in 1970 (specifically, the utilities included by the BLS in determining 1970 gross rent for the low-income budget) and increasing that cost over time in accord with the local fuel CPI. So, in this second role of utilities in our work, real utility consumption is held fixed. (We would have preferred fixing quantities in the housing bundle at some midpoint of the period under study, but the last BLS cross-city budget study was done in 1970.)

In constructing its rent index, BLS began accounting for depreciation of the units in 1988. We account for depreciation from 1970 to 1987.
